summary: This is a memorandum from U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman requesting approval for Assistant U.S. Attorneys to travel to Stockholm, Sweden, to interview a potential witness in the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and his associates. The witness is a relative of a victim and may provide critical corroboration and information related to violations of 18 U.S.C. ยง 2423 (transportation of minors for illicit sexual activity).

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York
persons.context: Author of the memorandum requesting approval for foreign travel of AUSAs to interview a witness in the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The investigation focuses on criminal conduct undertaken by him and his associates, specifically the transportation of minors for illicit sexual activity.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, is overseeing the investigation into Epstein's criminal conduct.

events.title: Planned travel to Sweden for witness interview
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorneys are scheduled to travel to Stockholm, Sweden, to interview a potential witness (a relative of a victim) in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Originally approved travel dates
events.description: The trip was originally approved for January 27 through 31, 2020, but was rescheduled to the following week due to approval timelines.

locations: The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was actively investigating Jeffrey Epstein and his associates for violations including 18 U.S.C. ยง 2423 (transportation of minors for illicit sexual activity) as of January 2020.

Prosecutors planned to travel to Sweden in February 2020 to interview a witness who is a relative of a victim and could significantly corroborate the victim's account and provide additional information critical to the investigation.
The witness was a citizen and resident of Sweden unable to travel due to medical issues, necessitating the prosecutors' travel to Stockholm.
The travel required High Threat Security Overseas Seminar (HTSOS) training for the Assistant U.S. Attorneys involved.
The document indicates the investigation was ongoing and involved international evidence gathering well after Epstein's death in August 2019.
